quote: Per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a large family of human-made chemicals that pose a major environmental and health issue globally.
PFAS exposure has detrimental health impacts on humans including cancer, thyroid diseases, hormonal changes, and reduced vaccine response, among others.
Breaking a C-F bond is a fundamental step in the degradation process of PFAS.
VQE is likely to remain the de facto method in this field for foreseeable future.
Due to the limitations of quantum computing simulators and hardware, we study the bond-breaking for smaller PFAS-like molecules such as CH 3F.
CH3F is the largest molecule that can be executed with a C-F bond in the quantum emulator.
The results show that VQE can capture correlations and provide accuracy beyond HF, especially for a bond-breaking experiment.
For this experiment, a geometry of the molecule is defined further away from the equilibrium geometry, trying to simulate how the stretch would be.
Thus, we evaluate PFAS-like molecules to break the C-F bond of them.
Remediation of global PFAS pollution is a an active research topic that aims at finding new mechanisms to destroy these substances.
A major pathway for PFAS destruction is breaking carbon-fluorine bonds.
